question: James gets 80 emails a day.  20% of those emails don't require any response.  He responds to the rest of them.  How many emails does he respond to in a 5 day work week?
answer:
He gets 80*.2=<<80*.2=16>>16 emails he doesn't need to respond to
So he responds to 80-16=<<80-16=64>>64 emails
So he responds to 64*5=<<64*5=320>>320 emails a week
#### 320
question_annotated:
{name,James} receives {n,80} emails a day. {p,20}% of those emails don't require any response. From the rest, {name,James} can only respond to {k,5} less than the {frac,half} of them. How many emails does {name,James} respond to in a {d,5} day work week? {name,James} work overtime on the last day so he can respond to {pp,10}% more emails than usual.

#init:
- name = sample(names_male)
- $n = range(10, 35)
- $p = range(5, 40)
- $k = range(2, 21)
- $frac = sample(fractions)
- $d = range(3, 7)
- $pp = range(5, 76, 5)

#conditions:
- is_int(n * p / 100)
- is_int(n * (100 - p) / 100)
- (n * (100 - p) / 100) * (frac) > k + 7
- is_int((n * (100 - p) / 100) * (frac))
- is_int((1+pp/100)*(((n * (100 - p) / 100) * frac)-k))

#answer: int((d-1) * (((n * (100 - p) / 100) * frac)-k)) + int((1+pp/100)*(((n * (100 - p) / 100) * frac)-k))
answer_annotated:
{name} receives {int(n * p / 100)}=<<{n}*{p}/100={n*p//100}>>{n*p//100} emails that don't require a response
So {n}-{n*p//100}=<<{n}-{n*p//100}={n*(100-p)//100}>>{n*(100-p)//100} emails will be left. Of those, {name} can respond to {frac} minus {k}. So {n*(100-p)//100} * {frac} - {k} = {int((n*(100-p)//100)*frac)-k} emails will be responded in a day.
In the first {d-1} day work week, {name} responds to {int((n*(100-p)//100)*frac)-k}*{d-1}=<<{int((n*(100-p)//100)*frac)-k}*{d-1}={(d-1)*(int((n*(100-p)//100)*frac)-k)}>> {(d-1)*(int((n*(100-p)//100)*frac)-k)} emails. 
In the last day, {name} responds to {pp}% more email so {pp}% * {int((n*(100-p)//100)*frac)-k} = {int((pp/100)*(int((n*(100-p)//100)*frac)-k))} emails. So on that day, he responds to {int(pp/100*(int((n*(100-p)//100)*frac)-k))} + {int((n*(100-p)//100)*frac)-k} = {int((1+pp/100)*(int((n*(100-p)//100)*frac)-k))} emails.
Overall, in {d} days, {name} responds to {(d-1)*(int((n*(100-p)//100)*frac)-k)} emails +{int((1+pp/100)*(int((n*(100-p)//100)*frac)-k))} emails = {int((d-1) * (((n * (100 - p) / 100) * frac)-k)) + int((1+pp/100)*(((n * (100 - p) / 100) * frac)-k))} emails.
#### {int((d-1) * (((n * (100 - p) / 100) * frac)-k)) + int((1+pp/100)*(((n * (100 - p) / 100) * frac)-k))}
